quest_title: A convex lens forms a real image of an object on a screen. The distance between object and screen is 75cm. On displacing the lens by 24cm towards the screen the real image on screen is again obtained. The focal length of lens is
explanation_txt: \(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{\mathrm{D}^{2}-\mathrm{x}^{2}}{4 \mathrm{D}}=\cfrac{75^{2}-24^{2}}{4 \times 75}=16.8 \mathrm{m}\)

\(\mathrm{y}=6 \sin \left(\cfrac{\pi x}{3}\right) \cdot \cos 40 \pi \mathrm{t}\)

Comparing with standard (std.) equation;

\(\mathrm{K}=\pi / 3\)

\(\lambda=2 \pi / \mathrm{k}=6 \mathrm{cm}\)

Separation between two adjacent nodes

\(=\lambda / 2=6 / 2=3 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: A man run due north at 2 m/s turns east and run at same speed. The change in velocity is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { Change in velocity }=\overrightarrow{v_{2}}-\overrightarrow{v_{1}}=\overrightarrow{v_{2}}+(-\overrightarrow{v_{1}})} \\ {\text { Magnitude of } \overrightarrow{v_{2}}-\overrightarrow{v_{1}}=\sqrt{v_{2}^{2}+v_{1}^{2}}} \\ {\quad \quad \quad=\sqrt{2^{2}+2^{2}}=\sqrt{8}=2 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { Tan } \alpha=\cfrac{v_{1}}{v_{2}}=\cfrac{2}{2}=1=\tan 45^{\circ}} \\ {\text { Tan } 45^{\circ} \text { (south east) }}\end{array}\)
question_plain_title: A man run due north at 2 m/s turns east and run at same speed. The change in velocity is
ans2_plain_text: 2 2 m/s south west
ans3_plain_text: 2 2 m/s south east
ans4_plain_text: 2 2 m/s north west

quest_title: A satellite of KE E is revolving around the earth in a circular orbit. The minimum additional energy required to escape it from orbit into outer space is
explanation_txt:
\(v_{0}=\sqrt{\cfrac{G M}{r}}\)

\(\mathrm{E}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{m} \cfrac{G M}{r}\)

To escape,

\(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{e}}=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 G M}{r}}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{E}^{\prime}=\cfrac{1}{2} \mathrm{m} \cfrac{2 G M}{r}=2 \mathrm{E}\)
\(\therefore\) Additional energy \(=\mathrm{E}^{\prime}-\mathrm{E}=E\)
question_plain_title: A satellite of KE E is revolving around the earth in a circular orbit. The minimum additional energy required to escape it from orbit into outer space is
explanation_plain_text:
To escape,


Additional energy

quest_title: Snow is more heat insulating than ice, because
ans1_txt: Air is filled in pores of snow
ans2_txt: Ice is more bad conductor than snow

quest_title: When white light passes through a glass prism, one gets spectrum on the other side of the prism. In the emergent beam, the ray which is deviating least is
explanation_txt:
Deviation of light by prism \(\delta = A(\mu -1)\) ..........(i)

Refractive index of prism (glass) for a light of wavelength \(\lambda\) is given by Cauchy's relation.

\(\mu=a+\cfrac{b}{\lambda^{2}}+\cfrac{c}{\lambda^{4}}\)

As all the constants \(a, b\) and \(c\) are positive, \(\mu \propto \cfrac{1}{\lambda}\)

Red light has highest wavelength amongst visible light rays, so refractive index is minimum for red light.

Hence from relation (i), deviation for red light is minimum.
question_plain_title: When white light passes through a glass prism, one gets spectrum on the other side of the prism. In the emergent beam, the ray which is deviating least is
explanation_plain_text:
Deviation of light by prism ..........(i)

Refractive index of prism (glass) for a light of wavelength is given by Cauchy's relation.

As all the constants and are positive,

Red light has highest wavelength amongst visible light rays, so refractive index is minimum for red light.

Hence from relation (i), deviation for red light is minimum.

quest_title: The idea of secondary wavelets for the propagation of a wave was first given by
explanation_txt: Huygen's principle states that every point of wavefront acts as a individual source producing secondary wavelets which travels in forward direction. The resulting new wavefront in the forward direction is due to superpoistion of these secondary wavelets.

explanation_txt:
Wave velocity \(v=f \times \lambda\)

\(=500 \times 0.1=50 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \)

Time taken by wave \(\mathrm{t}=\mathrm{d} / \mathrm{v}= \cfrac{300}{50}=6 \mathrm{sec} \)

quest_title: Sound waves from a whistle of frequency 1100Hz reaches a point by two different paths. When the path differ by 15cm or 45cm there is silence at that point. The speed of sound is
explanation_txt:
The path differ between maximum and minimum intensity is:
\(\lambda / 2\) or \((2 n-1) \lambda / 2\)
\(\lambda / 2=15\)
\(\Rightarrow \lambda=30\)
\(\mathrm{v}=\mathrm{f} \times \lambda=1100 \times 30 \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{sec}\)

quest_title: A sheet of paper 40mm wide and \(1.5\times 10^{-2}\,mm\) thick is inserted between metal foils of same width to make a \(2\mu F\) capacitor. The dielectric constant of material is \(2.5\) then length of paper is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{C}=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}} \varepsilon_{0} \mathrm{A}}{\mathrm{d}}\)
or, \(\mathrm{C}=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}} \varepsilon_{0} l \times \mathrm{b}}{\mathrm{d}}\)
or, \(l=\cfrac{2 \times 10^{-6} \times 1.5 \times 10^{-5}}{2.5 \times 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 40 \times 10^{-3}}\)
\(\qquad=33.8 \mathrm{m}\)

quest_title: A charged particle moving in a magnetic field experiences a resultant force
ans2_txt: In the direction opposite to that field
ans3_txt: In the direction perpendicular to both the field and its velocity
explanation_txt:
\(\overrightarrow{F} =q\left(\overrightarrow{v\, } \times \overrightarrow{B}\right) \)

\(\therefore\) The resultant force is pervendicular to the direction of velocity of charged particle and direction of magnetic field.
question_plain_title: A charged particle moving in a magnetic field experiences a resultant force
explanation_plain_text: The resultant force is pervendicular to the direction of velocity of charged particle and direction of magnetic field.
ans2_plain_text: In the direction opposite to that field
ans3_plain_text: In the direction perpendicular to both the field and its velocity

quest_title: An step-down transformer is connected to 2400 volts line and 80 amperes of current is found to flow in output load. The ratio of the turns in primary and secondary coil is 20 : 1. If transformer efficiency is 100%, then the current flowing in the primary coil will be
explanation_txt: \(\cfrac{I_{S}}{I_{P}}=\cfrac{n_{P}}{n_{S}} \Rightarrow \cfrac{80}{I_{P}}=\cfrac{20}{1} \Rightarrow I_{P}=4 \mathrm{Amp}\)

quest_title: If a magnet is suspended at an angle of 30\(^ \circ\) to the magnetic meridian, the dip needle makes an angle of 45\(^ \circ\) with the horizontal. The real dip is
explanation_txt:
Let the actual angle of dip (in the magnetic meridian) is '\(\theta\)'.

If \(B_H\) and \(B_V\) be the horizontal and vertical components of earth’s magnetic field respectively then,

\(\tan \theta=\left(\cfrac{B_{V}}{B_{H}}\right)\)

In the plane situated at \(30 ^ \circ\) with the magnetic meridian in figure, the horizontal component of earth’s magnetic field will be \(B_H \cos 30^ \circ\) while the vertical component will be \(B_V\). The angle of dip in the plane will be

\(\begin{aligned} & \tan 45^{\circ}=\cfrac{B_{V}}{B_{H} \cos 30^{\circ}} \\ \therefore & \cfrac{\tan \theta}{\tan 45^{\circ}}=\cos 30^{\circ} \quad \Rightarrow \tan \theta=\cfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \\ \therefore & \theta=\tan ^{-1}\left(\cfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) \end{aligned}\)
